In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the

of any territory or area. 
 
 The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
 members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Under  its  Strategy  2020, 1  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  has  identified 
environmentally  sustainable  growth,  including  infrastructure  and  climate  change,  as  a  top 
development  and  operational  priority.  Consistent  with  Strategy  2020,  ADB  is  refocusing 
operations in the transport sector to place greater emphasis on sustainability, as outlined in 
ADB’s Sustainable Transport Initiative–Operational Plan (STI–OP) approved in July 2010.2 The 
Sustainable Transport Initiative is being implemented under the guidance of ADB’s transport 
community of practice as a tool to help ADB adapt its transport operations to serve the changing 
needs of the developing member countries (DMCs). 
 
2.  The proposed technical assistance (TA) is a cluster TA project targeting three of the four 
key pillars for implementing sustainable transport under the STI–OP, namely: (i) urban transport, 
(ii)  climate  change  in  transport,  and  (iii)  road  safety  and  social  sustainability.  The  cluster 
approach is proposed because all the subprojects are in line with the STI–OP and inclusion in 
the cluster TA offers significant potential synergies while greatly reducing transaction costs for 
the TA project implementation.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  As defined in the STI–OP, a sustainable transport system is one that is accessible, safe, 
environment friendly, and affordable. In the Asia and Pacific region, a range of challenges face 
the sustainability of the transport sector. In particular, these include rapid motorization and 
urbanization that are affecting the social sustainability of transport, transport’s emergence as the 
largest and fastest growing sector for greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, high accident rates, a 
gap  in  transport  infrastructure  and  transport  services,  and  regional  integration  and  trade 
facilitation that is hampered by current arrangements for cross-border transport and logistics. 
This TA addresses urban transport, climate change, and social sustainability aspects of these 
challenges. ADB is already implementing substantial work on other STI–OP priorities, including 
cross-border transport and logistics through the Office of Regional Economic Integration, as well 
as activities on road safety that are currently being considered for other financing sources. 
 
4.  As a result of rising incomes, per capita vehicle ownership is rising exceptionally fast, 
and  especially  in  Asia’s  cities,  where  motor  vehicle  fleets  are  doubling  every  5–7  years. 
Emerging Asian countries are estimated to have added 35 million vehicles between 2006 and 
2009. These trends are placing an enormous strain on transport and mobility in urban areas. 
Road  congestion  already  costs  Asian  economies  an  estimated  2%–5%  of  gross  domestic 
product every year. Uncontrolled growth in urban road traffic and rising congestion are also 
compromising the health and safety of urban dwellers. The region's cities suffer from the highest 
air pollution levels in the world, with as much as 80% of that attributable to transport. According 
to World Health Organization data, air pollution—including that from transport—imposes an 
economic cost of up to 2%–4% of gross domestic product in many countries. 
 
5.  Rapid motorization and urbanization is also resulting in declining social sustainability of 
transport. About 70% (800 million) of the world’s poor live in Asia and, although poverty is 
sometimes perceived to be a rural phenomenon, the incidence of urban and peri-urban poverty 
is significant and growing. Almost 25% of Asia’s urban population is poor. About 250 million

2020. The decrease in modal share of nonmotorized transport (NMT), the increase in journey 
lengths due to urban design, and rising public transport costs are all making transport for the 
poor less affordable while depriving many of access to markets and services. 
 
6.  Energy use in the transport sector is dominated by petroleum product fuels, and the 
share of transport within total global GHG emissions, in particular carbon dioxide (CO ), is 
2
growing rapidly. In 2006, transport accounted for 13% of global GHG, while 23% of global CO  
2
emissions from fuel combustion were transport-related. The vast majority of projected increases 
are expected to come from developing Asia. Asia’s emissions from motorized transport have 
become a significant contributor to the global GHG problem that leads to climate change. While 
Asia accounted for 19% of total transport sector CO  emissions in 2006, by 2030 this figure is 
2
forecast to increase to 31% if current trends continue.  
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
7.  The TA project will develop subprojects at interregional, subregional, country, and city 
levels that contribute toward building capacity among DMCs to develop and implement policies, 
programs, and projects that will enhance the economic, social, and environmental sustainability 
of transport infrastructure and services. Increased capacity among DMCs will enable ADB to 
better align its existing and future transport operations with the three strategic agendas of 
Strategy 2020: inclusive economic growth, environmentally sustainable growth, and regional 
integration.  
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The impact of the TA will be to establish a trend toward enhanced sustainability of 
transport systems in participating DMCs in the Asia and Pacific region. The overall outcome of 
the cluster TA will be increased awareness of the critical importance of sustainability in transport 
system development, and a greater readiness and capacity of DMCs in the Asia and Pacific 
region to identify, develop, and implement sustainable transport policies, programs, and projects. 
This will be measured by the number of participating DMCs having initiated development of 
sustainable  transport-related  policies  while  having  identified  and  initiated  development  of 
sustainable transport programs and projects. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  The TA has six subprojects that together provide an integrated approach to addressing 
key aspects of the STI–OP’s pillars. Additional subprojects, or topping up of initial subprojects, 
may be proposed later. The subprojects are: 
 
10.  Subproject A: Greenhouse gas assessment methodologies in sustainable public 
transport. This subproject will support STI–OP pillar (ii), climate change in transport. It will 
develop a GHG calculator that can be integrated into the existing planning and management of 
public transport operating companies. The main target group is public transport operators and 
government entities regulating these companies. Many existing tools for assessing the GHG 
impacts of public transport operations and investments are too complex for regular use by public 
transport managers. New sketch-type methodologies, such as the transportation  emissions 
evaluation model for projects, offer the potential cost-effectively to provide emission estimates in 
a  user-friendly  manner.  The  subproject  will  refine  the  existing  transportation  emissions 
evaluation model for projects GHG calculator and apply the methodology in selected cities in

3 
several DMCs, develop a recognition program for bus operating firms achieving excellence in 
GHG reduction, examine barriers to mainstreaming climate change into operations, suggest 
ways to overcome these barriers, and recommend financing options for their implementation.  
 
11.  Subproject B: New approaches to implement sustainable low-carbon transport in 
the Asia and Pacific region. This subproject also will support STI–OP pillar (ii) climate change 
in transport. It will address climate change in transport through knowledge and conceptual 
approaches for sustainable transport support in key subsectors, including railways, inland water 
transport, urban transport, and freight and logistics. Activities under this subproject will help to 
identify and address barriers preventing DMCs from strengthening these subsectors and will 
identify  future  lending  opportunities  for  these  subsectors.  This  subproject  will  support 
identification,  processing,  and/or  implementation  of  sustainable  low-carbon  ADB  transport 
projects. Such support will enable mitigation activities to be incorporated into project selection 
and design, allow assessing GHG impacts of specific project components, and support capacity 
building on mitigating climate change through transport-related activities. It also will help source 
additional climate finance from such mechanisms as the Global Environment Facility, Clean 
Development Mechanism, and/or nationally appropriate mitigation actions.  
 
12.  Subproject  C:  Promoting  socially  sustainable  transport  through  improving 
nonmotorized transport. This subproject will support STI–OP pillar (iv) social sustainability. It 
will pilot NMT components aimed at improving integrated and inclusive public transport systems 
in DMCs. Improving walking and cycling facilities while linking these to improved public transport 
will help provide affordable door-to-door mobility. The results of these pilots will be utilized in 
designing regional guidelines on integrating NMT with public transport systems. This subproject 
will (i) support the addition of NMT components to existing ADB transport projects, (ii) help 
catalyze new NMT initiatives, and (iii) provide formal social impact analysis of selected ADB 
transport projects. The support will deliver high-quality demonstration efforts and create the 
methodological basis for future social impact analysis of ADB projects. This subproject also will 
provide  demonstration  units  of  NMT  technologies  (e.g.,  public  bicycles  and  pedicabs)  for 
outreach purposes to cities. 
 
13.  Subproject  D:  Better  transport  data  for  sustainable  transport  policies  and 
investment planning. This subproject will help improve the availability and quality of transport 
data in the Asia and Pacific region and thus provide direct inputs to each of the STI–OP pillars. 
Current data availability and quality limit the development of sustainable transport policies and 
investment  strategies  and  constrain  the  ability  to  evaluate  impacts  of  such  policies  and 
investments.  The  subproject  will  establish  historical  (2000–2010)  data  sets  on  transport 
infrastructure and services as well as their social and environmental impacts. Moreover, it will 
provide an outlook up to 2030. To reduce the risk that the data collection activities would be 
limited to a one-off exercise, ADB has been consulting with other organizations to develop a 
more permanent mechanism for transport data.  
 
14.  Subproject  E:  Intelligent  transport  systems  for  better  urban  transport.  This 
subproject will address STI–OP pillar (i) urban transport. It will contribute to the development of 
strategies  for  implementing  information  and  communication  technologies  for  better  public 
transport service and travel demand management in urban areas. In particular, it will focus on 
integrated ticketing and vehicle management systems based upon an on-board fuel and GHG 
indicator  unit,  wireless communication,  and global  positioning  systems. The  subproject  will 
review the state of the art in these areas and conduct case studies of several cities in Asia. 
Guidelines and recommendations will be developed on how best to use intelligent transport

4   
systems in ADB projects on sustainable urban transport presently in processing and in future 
projects. 
 
15.  Subproject  F:  Innovative  financing  of  sustainable  transport  through  market 
mechanisms. Capturing value from externalities offers the potential to greatly enhance and 
diversify existing financing portfolios for sustainable transport initiatives. It is recognized that 
carbon markets to date are not sufficient in and of themselves to alter project economics. For 
this reason, capturing value from other sources, such as energy security, air quality and health, 
and  road  safety,  will  assist  in making  projects  bankable.  ADB  has  already  developed  the 
rationale behind a scheme for fuel security credits and has undertaken conceptual work on the 
idea of health credits. ADB has also conducted research on parking levies, land value capture, 
and congestion pricing. This subproject will support the development of a pilot demonstration of 
new mechanisms, as well as strengthen the conceptual basis for emerging mechanisms. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The  estimated  total  cost  of  the  TA  is  $6.698  million,  broken  down  as  follows:  (i) 
subproject A: $1.00 million, (ii) subproject B: $2.298 million, (iii) subproject C: $2.00 million, (iv) 
subproject D: $1.00 million, (v) subproject E: $0.30 million, and (vi) subproject F: $0.10 million. 
The aggregate cost will be financed on a grant basis as follows: (i) $1.00 million from ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV), (ii) $2.398 million from ADB’s Climate Change 
Fund4, (iii) $1.00 million from the Global Environment Facility and administered by ADB, (iv) 
$2.00 million from the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and administered by ADB, and (v) 
$0.30  million  from  the  Republic  of  Korea  e-Asia  and  Knowledge  Partnership  Fund  and 
administered by ADB. The cost estimates and financing plan are detailed in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  ADB  will  coordinate  the  TA  through  ADB  Regional  and  Sustainable  Development 
Department  (RSDD).  Once  the  cluster  TA  is  approved,  the  subproject  proposals  will  be 
submitted for approval to the director general of RSDD, in accordance with ADB guidelines on 
cluster TA processing.5 ADB will be the executing agency for each subproject.  
 
18.  The TA will benefit from updated implementation arrangements which are being put in 
place for implementing the STI–OP. These include establishment of the STI–OP management 
committee consisting of transport and urban development directors. It is intended that the STI–
OP management committee6 will have an important role in overseeing implementation of the TA. 
In addition, advisory teams7 which have been set up under the transport community of practice 
for the main transport subsectors targeted by ADB transport operations and the main themes of 
the  STI–OP  (e.g.,  climate  change  and  social  sustainability)  will  play  an  active  role  in 
implementing  the  different  subprojects.  No  new  additional  institutional  arrangements  will, 
therefore,  need  to  be  created  to  ensure  full  participation  of  the  regional  departments  in 
implementing the TA. Direct responsibility for overall implementation of the TA will rest with the 
RSDD/Sustainable  Infrastructure  Division,  which  also  will  coordinate  with  the  regional

19.   In parallel to the financing and administration of the TA by ADB, the Government 
of the Republic of Korea (Ministry of Strategy and Finance) will provide in-kind collaboration of 
about $0.30 million through the Knowledge Sharing Program, which is administered by Export-
8
Import Bank of the Republic of Korea.  This in-kind collaboration of the Government of the 
Republic of Korea will be provided for Subproject E (intelligent transport systems for better 
urban transport). 
 
20.  The TA project is expected to be implemented from December 2011 to June 2014. The 
TA will require national consulting inputs of 124–186 person-months and international consulting 
inputs  of  264–330  person-months.  Consulting  inputs  will  be  required  from  both  firms  and 
individuals  under  quality-  and  cost-based  selection  with  a  quality-cost  ratio  of  80:20.  All 
consultants  will  be  engaged  by  ADB  in  accordance  with  its  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Given that this is a cluster TA project, 
consultant  selection  will  apply  different  methods  depending  on the size  and  nature  of the 
contracts. The outline terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3. In limited cases, 
equipment will be required for demonstration purposes under the subprojects and for site offices. 
All procurement of goods and other services under the TA will be made in accordance with 
ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). Upon completion of the 
TA,  all  equipment  procured  by  the  consultants  under the TA  will  be turned  over  to  ADB. 
Disbursements will be made in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement 
Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION AND DECISION 
21.  The President recommends that the Board approve (i) ADB administering a portion of 
the technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $2,000,000 to be financed on a grant 
basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction; and (ii) ADB providing a portion of the technical 
assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $3,398,000 on a grant basis for Implementation of 
Sustainable Transport in Asia and the Pacific. If the Board approves ADB administering and 
providing the technical assistance, the President, acting under the authority delegated by the 
Board, will approve (i) ADB administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the 
equivalent of $1,000,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Global Environment Facility; 
and (ii) ADB administering the balance of the technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent 
of $300,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge 
Partnership Fund for Implementation of Sustainable Transport in Asia and the Pacific.

5.3 Prepare a tool kit for use in raising awareness of ITS options and building 
capacity for implementing ITS in sustainable urban public transport.  
 
6. Subproject F: Innovative financing of sustainable transport through 
market mechanisms 
 
Inception phase: Q1 2012 
Prepare detailed implementation plan and select consultants. 
 
Implementation phase: Q2 2012–Q2 2014 
6.1 Develop concepts for a pilot fund on fuel security credits, and identify its 
potential contributors. Prepare the appropriate protocol and administrative 
documentation for operationalizing the pilot fund. 
6.2 Develop concepts for health credits and other market mechanisms, which 
may include land value capture, parking levies, and congestion pricing.

Appendix 3  13 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The project will consist of a core management team that will oversee and manage the 
running of the constituent subprojects, facilitate linkages between the  project and the wider 
activities of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) transport community of practice, and engage 
external partners. A range of consultancy inputs will be needed to implement specific subprojects. 
It is anticipated that individual consultants will be retained for most activities, but where activities 
would best be packaged and managed independently, consulting firms may be retained. 
 
2.  The  cluster  technical  assistance  (TA)  projects  will  require  the  services  of  experts  in 
greenhouse  gas  (GHG)  assessment,  sustainable  transport  policy  and  planning,  information 
systems, intelligent transport systems (ITS), and market mechanisms. The detailed terms of 
reference (TOR), numbers of consultancy inputs, and consultant selection methods will be defined 
during subproject processing in accordance with ADB’s procedures for cluster TA projects. Key 
tasks to be performed by consultants under each subproject are outlined below. Subprojects A–F 
may employ individuals and/or consulting firms.. 
 
A.  Subproject A: Greenhouse gas assessment methodologies in sustainable public 
transport 
 
3.  With  an  emphasis  on  bus  rapid  transit,  this  subproject  will  enhance  existing 
methodologies for assessing GHG and local environmental impacts of bus operations. The 
subproject  will  work  to  improve  the  accuracy,  user-friendliness,  and  cost-effectiveness  of 
models, such as the transportation emissions evaluation model for projects.  The latter model 
will be refined and then trialed in several (3–4) Asian cities. The results will be disseminated 
through workshops, a manual, and online resources. The aim is to produce a practical and 
broadly applicable tool for GHG assessment of current and planned public transport operations 
which can be mainstreamed into the public transport sector.  
 
4.  GHG  methodology  specialist,  transport  specialists,  business  development  and/or 
financial specialists, recognition program specialist (international, 18–24 person-months) and 
transport specialists, business development/financial specialists, recognition program specialist, 
web designer (national, 24-30 person-months) will carry out the following activities: 
(i)  Review past work on GHG methodologies and lessons from case studies in 
relation  to  data  requirements,  model  structure,  alternatives,  and  accuracy  of 
results. 
(ii)  Review the existing the transportation emissions evaluation model for projects 
model for bus rapid transit and refine it based upon expert inputs and the lessons 
learned from the case study review. 
(iii)  Validate  and  further  refine  the  model  using  case  studies  of  public  transport 
projects and operations in several (3–4) Asian cities. 
(iv)  Identify policy, technical, financial, institutional, and other barriers which hamper 
the  mainstreaming  of  climate  change  considerations  in  operations  of  public 
transport operators. 
(v)  Work with public transport companies in the case study cities to incorporate into 
their  business  plans  climate  change-oriented  sustainability  indicators  and 
systems for periodic measurement. 
(vi)  Develop a recognition program for bus companies which incorporate the quality 
components and fulfill system monitoring requirements. 
(vii)  Test the recognition program with a selected group of bus operating companies.

14   Appendix 3   
 
 
(viii)  Investigate financing mechanisms and develop recommendations on conditions 
and methodologies under which public transport operators can better access 
climate  finance  (such  as  the  Clean  Development  Mechanism  and  nationally 
appropriate mitigation actions) for mainstreaming climate change considerations 
in public transport. 
(ix)  Prepare a manual and/or tool kit on the sustainable transport GHG calculation 
and planning tool, as well as an online, user-friendly version of the sustainable 
transport GHG calculator suitable for access through such websites as those of 
ADB,  Clean  Air  Initiative  for  Asian  Cities,  International  Association  of  Public 
Transport, Sustainable Urban Transport Project, and Institute for Transportation 
and Development Policy. 
(x)  Conduct workshops with the case study cities and a regional workshop to explain 
use of the sustainable transport GHG calculator and to mainstream its application. 
(xi)  Prepare a project completion report summarizing the project process, findings, 
and recommendations. 
 
B.  Subproject B: New approaches to implement sustainable low-carbon transport in 
the Asia and Pacific region 
 
5.  This  subproject  will  investigate  low-carbon  project  concepts  for  inland  waterways, 
railways, freight, and urban transport. It provides support to strengthen the climate-mitigation 
orientation of transport operations. 
 
6.  Transport  specialists,  institutional  specialists,  economic  and/or  financial  specialists, 
engineers  (international,  36–48  person-months)  and  (transport  specialists,  institutional 
specialists, economic/ financial specialists, engineers (national, 78–90 person-months) will carry 
out the following activities: 
(i)  Review current best practice and emerging opportunities for adopting low-carbon 
transport  concepts  in  developing  member  countries  (DMCs)  in  the  following 
subsectors that have so far received limited  attention: railways, inland water 
transport, urban transport, freight and logistics, nonmotorized transport (NMT), 
and travel demand management. 
(ii)  Provide support to all ADB transport projects under identification, processing, or 
implementation. This will include at least 15 transport operations in ADB (at 
project or country partnership strategy level) to incorporate GHG mitigation as 
part  of  project  design; assess GHG  impacts  of  specific  project  components; 
and/or support capacity building on climate change mitigation and procurement of 
additional climate finance from mechanisms such as the Global Environment 
Facility,  Clean  Development  Mechanism,  or  nationally  appropriate  mitigation 
actions.  
(iii)  Identify barriers that are holding back DMCs from broader adoption of low-carbon 
transport  concepts  in  these  sectors,  then  recommend  practical  and  effective 
measures to address these barriers. 
(iv)  Identify (5–6) demonstration projects for low-carbon transport initiatives in DMCs. 
The projects will be chosen to cover different target subsectors and a range of 
urban  and  regional  contexts  in  Asia.  Possible  project  locations  include 
Bangladesh, the People’s Republic of China, India, and Central and West Asia. 
(v)  Conduct prefeasibility studies and prepare concept papers for the demonstration 
projects, then conduct workshops to present and disseminate findings.  
(vi)  Identify  ADB  lending  opportunities  for  low-carbon  transport  initiatives  in  the 
subsectors covered by this project.

Appendix 3  15 
(vii)  Prepare  a  tool  kit  for  including  low-carbon  transport  concepts  into  transport 
projects.  
(viii)  Conduct  a  regional  forum  to  share  information  about  low-carbon  transport 
opportunities and case studies, as well as to launch the low-carbon transport tool 
kit. 
(ix)  Develop descriptive and summary materials on concepts for inclusion into the 
ADB transport website. 
(x)  Prepare a project completion report summarizing the project process, findings, 
and recommendations. 
 
C.  Subproject  C:  Promoting  socially  sustainable  transport  through  improving 
nonmotorized transport 
 
7.  The subproject will carry out capacity development and prefeasibility studies for pro-poor 
NMT in several (3–4) cities in DMCs. Through advisory support, stakeholder sessions, and 
training of government officials, the TA will assist local agencies in the respective cities and 
countries to plan, finance, and implement programs and develop projects focusing on NMT 
measures. The lessons from these pilot programs will form a basis for broader inclusion of NMT 
into ADB programs. 
 
8.  Urban  planning  and  NMT  experts,  social  development  and/or  gender  specialists, 
monitoring and evaluation specialists (international, 30–42 person-months) and urban planning 
and NMT experts, social development specialists (national, 48–60 person-months) will carry out 
the following activities: 
(i)  Review current best practice and emerging opportunities for adoption of NMT 
concepts in transport planning within DMCs. 
(ii)  Provide support to all ADB transport projects under identification, processing, or 
implementation.  This  will  support  additional  work  on  at  least  15  transport 
operations in ADB (at project or country partnership strategy level) to incorporate 
NMT components into project design. 
(iii)  Work with local and national governments in 3–4 cities to identify specific NMT 
project interventions and prepare preliminary cost estimates for these initiatives. 
Possible project locations include Astana (Kazakhstan), Dhaka (Bangladesh), Ho 
Chi Minh City (Viet Nam), Pasig City (Philippines), Surabaya (Indonesia), Tbilisi 
(Georgia), and Vientiane (Lao People’s Democratic Republic). 
(iv)  Assess  the  current  barriers  to  greater  recognition  of  NMT’s  role  and  its 
incorporation into formal planning processes in case study communities. Devise 
strategies to overcome such barriers and make NMT a safe and viable option, 
especially for low-income communities. 
(v)  Recommend formal NMT policies that can be adopted into the local and national 
policy framework. Build the NMT policy and planning capacity of national and 
local governments through training workshops with the pilot cities. 
(vi)  Conduct stakeholder engagement sessions to ensure the NMT projects meet the 
needs of the local communities and conduct social impact assessments. 
(vii)  Identify financing options to implement the proposed NMT initiatives, including 
options such as land value capture, parking levies, private sector partnerships 
with NMT vehicle suppliers, consignment purchase schemes, and installment 
payments for low-income residents. 
(viii)  Plan and design the NMT infrastructure required to provide a safe and secure 
environment for pedestrians and cyclists. The plans will also adopt universal 
design principles to ensure access for people with special needs.

16   Appendix 3   
 
 
(ix)  Formulate long-term management and maintenance plans that ensure the project 
components are sustained over the life of the infrastructure. 
(x)  Develop TOR and specifications for demonstration units of modernized pedicabs, 
public bicycles, and pedestrian infrastructure components for outreach efforts 
with  cities  and  other  key  stakeholders,  then,  assist  in  disseminating  these 
demonstration units. 
(xi)  Build the capacity of local governments for implementing financial plans that will 
provide for pilot NMT initiatives into low-income communities.  
(xii)  Summarize concepts and project outcomes for inclusion into ADB’s transport 
website. 
(xiii)  Prepare a project completion report summarizing the project process, findings, 
and recommendations. 
 
D.  Subproject  D:  Better  transport  data  for  sustainable  transport  policies  and 
investment planning 
 
9.  This subproject is an important step toward filling a major gap in the availability and 
quality of transport data for planning and assessment of sustainable transport policies and 
investment strategies in the Asia and Pacific region. 
 
10.  Transport data experts (international, 18–30 person-months) and transport data experts, 
information systems specialists (national, 48–60 person-months) will carry out the following 
activities: 
(i)  Identify  and  define transport  data series  required for  improved  planning  and 
assessment of sustainable transport policies and investment strategies in the 
Asia and Pacific region. The scope should cover transport infrastructure and 
services, as well as their social and environmental impacts. 
(ii)  Review the current availability of such transport data for the Asia and Pacific 
region and identify data gaps. 
(iii)  Collate historical (2000–2010) data sets where data is currently available, and 
develop a strategy to fill identified data gaps or develop alternative indicators. All 
sources and assumptions should be clearly identified and documented. 
(iv)  Design a user-friendly database system suitable for off-line or online access, then 
populate the database. 
(v)  Provide an outlook data series up to 2030 (and possibly 2050, if feasible) and 
incorporate these forecasts into the database. To the extent possible, data for 
future years should be based on official or internationally recognized forecasts. 
All sources and assumptions should be clearly identified and documented. 
(vi)  Recommend a cost-effective process for maintaining and updating the transport 
database. 
(vii)  Prepare  a  data  manual  that  describes  each  of  the  data  series  (including 
definitions,  sources,  assumptions,  and  updating  processes)  and  a  database 
manual that describes the structure and operation of the database and data 
access software. 
(viii)  Prepare a project completion report summarizing the project process, findings, 
and recommendations. 
 
E.  Subproject E: Intelligent transport systems for better urban transport 
 
11.  This subproject will review the state of the art and develop and disseminate guidelines 
for ITS in the DMCs to improve public transport service and travel demand management. This

Appendix 3  17 
will include case studies of several cities in Asia, focusing on the general lessons relevant to 
Asian cities at different levels of development. 
 
12.  ITS specialists (international, 8–12 person-months) and ITS specialists (national, 8–12 
person-months) will carry out the following activities: 
(i)  Review the state of the art in (a) integrated ticketing and vehicle management 
systems  based  upon  an  on-board  fuel  and  GHG  indicator  unit,  wireless 
communication, and global positioning systems; and (b) ITS options for traffic 
management (such as congestion charging and low-emission zones). 
(ii)  Conduct case studies of how these technologies have been implemented  at 
several locations in Asia (such as the Republic of Korea and Bangkok, Thailand), 
focusing on the general lessons relevant to Asian cities at different levels of 
development. 
(iii)  Prepare guidelines and recommendations on how best to make use of these 
aspects of ITS in urban transport operations and management, especially in 
relation to planned and future ADB projects in sustainable urban transport. 
(iv)  Prepare  a  tool  kit  for  use  in  raising  awareness  of  ITS  options  and  building 
capacity for implementing ITS in sustainable urban public transport.  
(v)  Conduct a regional workshop to share the key lessons of the study and launch 
the tool kit. 
(vi)  Prepare a project completion report summarizing the project process, findings, 
and recommendations. 
 
F.  Subproject  F:  Innovative  financing  of  sustainable  transport  through  market 
mechanisms 
 
13.  This subproject will lead the innovation of market mechanisms to capture value from 
externality  impacts  of  existing  transport  patterns  and  translate  them  into  resources  for 
sustainable transport interventions. Specifically, this subproject will include the piloting of a 
scheme  for  fuel  security  credits,  continue  development  of  the  health  credit  concept,  and 
investigate the feasibility of additional mechanisms. 
 
14.  Fund development specialists (international, 4 person-months) and fund development 
support specialists (national, 4 months]) will carry out the following activities: 
(i)  Assist in establishing the required core funding for a pilot fund on fuel security 
credits. 
(ii)  Conduct outreach sessions with governments, foundations, and private sector 
stakeholders who may contribute to the pilot fund. 
(iii)  Prepare  the  appropriate  protocol  and  administrative  documentation  for 
operationalizing the pilot fund. 
(iv)  Prepare TOR for the detailed design of the health credit concept. 
(v)  Prepare conceptual TOR for additional market mechanisms, which may include 
land value capture, parking levies, and congestion pricing. 
(vi)  Develop summary materials for inclusion into ADB’s transport website.
